author: By Rick Rojas
title: The Mississippi clinic at the center of the Supreme Court case is still open.
description: Jackson Women’s Health has seen an increase in patients, many from states like Texas and Louisiana that have restricted access to abortions.
content: The morning after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion in a case concerning Mississippi’s only abortion provider, ​​Derenda Hancock arrived at the clinic around sunrise, just as she does most days, to lead a group of volunteers escorting patients. Wednesday morning, the group was back to do it again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: She Put the Met on the Map for Contemporary Art. Now She’s Moving On.
description: Sheena Wagstaff revitalized the Met’s modern and contemporary art department and staked her legacy on experiments like the Met Breuer.
content: Sheena Wagstaff would often visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the 1980s when she was an arts student, seeking refuge among the Buddhas and bodhisattvas of the Asian art department. Her appointment in 2012 as the museum’s top curator of modern and contemporary art brought the most overshadowed department in America’s leading museum an acclaimed international exhibition program that included Kerry James Marshall, Gerhard Richter, David Hockney, Lygia Pape, Jack Whitten and Siah Armajani.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: As Leak Theories Circulate, Supreme Court Marshal Takes Up Investigation
description: Not since Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein refused for decades to disclose the identity of their Watergate source has Washington been as eager to unmask a leaker.
content: WASHINGTON — Maybe it was a liberal law clerk who leaked the draft opinion in the Supreme Court’s biggest case in years, hoping to gin up outrage among Democrats at the prospect of an end to legal abortions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Intelligence Is Helping Ukraine Kill Russian Generals, Officials Say
description: Targeting assistance is part of a classified effort by the Biden administration to provide real-time battlefield intelligence to Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States has provided intelligence about Russian units that has allowed Ukrainians to target and kill many of the Russian generals who have died in action in the Ukraine war, according to senior American officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Marcus Leatherdale, Portraitist of Downtown Manhattan, Dies at 69
description: He was the Cecil Beaton of New York City’s demimonde during the AIDS years, making elegant portraits of Andy Warhol, Keith Haring and Madonna.
content: Marcus Leatherdale, who made classical portraits of Manhattan’s demimonde in the 1980s — Keith Haring, Andy Warhol and Sydney Biddle Barrows, otherwise known as the Mayflower Madam, all made their way to his Lower East Side studio — died on April 22 at his home in the state of Jharkhand, India. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Judy Henske, a Distinctive Voice on the Folk Scene, Dies at 85
description: Her versatile vocals were a trademark, as was her comic stage patter. The character Annie Hall owed her a debt.
content: Judy Henske, who made a splash on the folk scene of the early 1960s with a versatile voice that could conjure Billie Holiday or foreshadow Janis Joplin, and performances full of offbeat stage patter, died on April 27 in hospice care in Los Angeles. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: In France, a Film Has Women Sharing Their Stories of Abortion
description: Following the release of “Happening,” about an illegal abortion in 1963, the country’s contemporary stigma around the procedure is facing scrutiny.
content: PARIS — “Happening,” Audrey Diwan’s film about a 1960s back-street abortion in France, isn’t for the fainthearted. In fact, audience members have fainted at several screenings, including at the Venice Film Festival last September, where it won the Golden Lion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: I Just Want My Kid to Learn Algebra. Does That Make Me a Culture Warrior?
description: Americans still underperform in math. That, not debates about testing and social emotional learning, should be our focus.
content: Last month, Florida rejected dozens of math textbooks because, the state found, they “included references to critical race theory” or had “inclusions of Common Core” or “the unsolicited addition of social emotional learning.” The New York Times reporters Dana Goldstein and Stephanie Saul reviewed 21 of the rejected books and said that while “in most of the books, there was little that touched on race,” they did include aspects of S.E.L., which they described as “a practice with roots in psychological research that tries to help students develop mind-sets that can support academic success.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What questions do you have about investing?
description: Send them to us and we’ll pass them along to Jeff Sommer, who writes the investing column Strategies.
content: It’s a challenging time to invest, with inflation and rising interest rates. Our columnist will help answer any questions you have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: dour
description: This word has appeared in 62 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word dour has appeared in 62 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 4 in “Take a Look at the Inspirations Behind ‘The Witcher’” by Elisabeth Vincentelli:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed Is Set to Pull Back Economic Help Rapidly. Is It Too Late?
description: Federal Reserve officials took a while to recognize that inflation was lasting. The question is whether they can tame it gently now.
content: The Federal Reserve is poised to set out a path to rapidly withdraw support from the economy at its meeting on Wednesday — and while it hopes it can contain inflation without causing a recession, that is far from guaranteed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson
title: As Victory Day Looms in Russia, Guesswork Grows Over Putin’s Ukraine Goals
description: The Russian holiday celebrating the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany is viewed by Ukraine and NATO as a stage for the Russian president to proclaim a turn in the war.
content: With the Russian military still struggling, Western officials and Ukraine’s traumatized residents are looking with increased alarm to Russia’s Victory Day holiday on May 9 — a celebration of the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany — fearing that President Vladimir V. Putin may exploit it as a grandiose stage to intensify attacks and mobilize his citizenry for all-out war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani and Michael Forsythe
title: Putin-Linked Superyacht May Elude Sanctions, by Setting Sail
description: The Italian police are in a race to finish investigating a $700 million vessel thought to be the Russian president’s — before it’s out of their reach.
content: MARINA DI CARRARA, Italy— The Italian police are in a race to finish investigating the ownership of a $700 million superyacht, which U.S. officials say is linked to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, before the vessel is put to sea and able to elude possible sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: Watch the Eta Aquariid Meteor Shower Peak in Night Skies
description: Fireballs may light up the sky for those willing to stay up late and take in the show.
content: Wednesday night into Thursday morning will be one of the special dates scattered throughout each year when skywatchers can catch a meteor shower as a multitude of flares potentially burst in the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Makes Biggest Interest Rate Increase Since 2000 as High Inflation Persists
description: The Federal Reserve is combating the fastest price increases in four decades and is trying to cool the economy before high inflation becomes embedded.
content: The Federal Reserve ramped up its attack on rapid inflation on Wednesday, approving its biggest interest rate increase since 2000, detailing a plan to shrink its massive bond holdings and signaling that it will continue working to cool the economy as it tries to tamp down the fastest price increases in four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why Your Garden Needs Mulch (Assuming You Do It Right)
description: Used correctly, mulch builds and improves your soil like nothing else. But don’t make these common mistakes.
content: Mulch provides so many services in the garden, from retaining soil moisture to suppressing weeds. But we often forget the most important one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Happy. Sad. Angry? Golden State Is Feeling It All Against Memphis.
description: A tense playoff series against the Grizzlies has Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Draymond Green reliving the emotional roller coaster of their championship runs.
content: MEMPHIS — The Golden State Warriors expected a physical fight in Game 2 of their second-round N.B.A. playoff series with the Memphis Grizzlies. But to lose that game, 106-101, and to lose a beloved defender to a fractured elbow? Those events they did not expect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in France: An Updated 19th-Century Farm on a French Island
description: Demand in the La Rochelle region, as in many second-home markets and areas amenable to remote work, has grown sharply in recent years.
content: This five-bedroom house, built in 1821 as a small farm before being converted to a family residence in 1894, sits in the heart of the quaint port town of La Flotte, on the island of Île de Ré, just off France’s mid-Atlantic coast. The two-story villa, on about a tenth of an acre, wraps around a courtyard garden of almost 1,800 square feet, with dining and relaxation areas, wall-clinging vines and a grand olive tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Elon Musk suggests Twitter could charge commercial and government accounts.
description: Mr. Musk, who has a deal to buy the platform, said accounts for casual users would always remain free.
content: Elon Musk, the Tesla chief executive who plans to acquire Twitter, suggested on Wednesday that it was possible the social network would charge certain users fees in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Kellen Browning
title: J.R. Majewski, a G.O.P. House nominee, has expressed fringe views on QAnon and Jan. 6.
description: Mr. Majewski, a surprise victor this week in Ohio, has voiced sympathy for QAnon believers and suggested that the F.B.I. drove much of the violence at the Capitol riot.
content: When J.R. Majewski emerged as the surprise winner of a Republican House primary election on Tuesday in northern Ohio, Democrats supporting the longtime incumbent congresswoman in the district, Marcy Kaptur, celebrated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Uber continues its recovery from the pandemic lull but loses $5.6 billion from investments.
description: Revenue in the first three months of 2022 was up 136 percent from a year earlier as travel continued to rebound.
content: Uber on Wednesday reported strong growth in its ride-hailing and delivery businesses and said it was continuing to bounce back from a pandemic slump, even as it lost $5.6 billion because of its investments in other ride-sharing companies, primarily the Chinese service Didi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: In ‘Nasty, Brutish, and Short,’ Kids Say the Most Epistemological Things
description: Scott Hershovitz takes readers on a tour of philosophy, guided by his two sons.
content: Is it moral to write publicly about your children?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: ‘You Haven’t Seen Anything Yet’: What’s Next if Roe Goes
description: A conversation on the extraordinary Supreme Court leak that could forever change reproductive rights in America.
content: It was a historic twist in an already historic case: A draft opinion of a Supreme Court decision overturning two landmark rulings — Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Casey — leaked to Politico, which published the 98-page document on Monday night. Chief Justice John Roberts said that the draft opinion was authentic but that “it does not represent a decision by the court or the final position of any member on the issues in the case.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Roe Inspired Activists Worldwide, Who May Be Rethinking Strategy
description: Feminist movements in some countries similarly sought abortion protections in their courts, but for others, the goal was legislative change.
content: The draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade that leaked Monday night is not yet final. But when the dust settles, American women may conclude that they had lost the right to abortion the same way that an Ernest Hemingway character said he had gone bankrupt: gradually, and then suddenly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Longwell
title: There’s No Reason to Think Republicans Are Ready to Move On From Trump
description: J.D. Vance’s win in Ohio is the latest proof.
content: J.D. Vance’s come-from-behind victory in the Ohio Republican primary was the first test of Donald Trump’s influence in 2022 election cycle as well as the future of the Republican Party. Spoiler alert: He’s influential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Tucker Carlson Is Proof That the Customer Isn’t Always Right
description: It’s one thing when you’re selling breakfast cereal. It’s another thing when you’re selling news.
content: Economists generally believe that more information makes for better decisions. But when it comes to the news business, you have to wonder. The more that producers and editors know about their audiences, the more they’re tempted to give them exactly what they want. “The customer is always right” is a fine principle when the product is breakfast cereal but problematic when you’re selling news and opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Stanford Gets $1.1 Billion for New Climate School From John Doerr
description: The billionaire venture capitalist said the study of climate change and sustainability would be the “new computer science.”
content: John Doerr, one of the most successful venture capitalists in the history of Silicon Valley, is giving $1.1 billion to Stanford University to fund a school focused on climate change and sustainability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Four Reasons the End of Roe v. Wade Terrifies Me
description: In revoking a right most Americans want, the Supreme Court risks doing tremendous damage to the country — and to itself.
content: Being braced for something and being ready for it aren’t the same. The reversal of Roe v. Wade is a case in point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks plans wage increases that won’t apply to unionized workers.
description: The initiative was announced as labor organizers have won initial votes at more than 50 stores, including several this week.
content: Starbucks announced Tuesday that it was raising pay and expanding training at corporate-owned locations in the United States. But it said the changes would not apply to the recently unionized stores, or to stores that may be in the process of unionizing, such as those where workers have filed a petition for a union election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: I Followed Some of Brazil’s Right-Wing Telegram Groups. I Found a Tide of Madness.
description: The problem is much bigger than a few scattered posts by lunatics.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — When Elon Musk reached a deal to acquire Twitter, right-wing Telegram groups in Brazil went wild. Here at last was a muscular champion of free speech. Even more, here was someone who — users rushed to confirm — wanted Carlos Bolsonaro, son of the president, to be Twitter’s managing director in Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Saving Ukrainian Art, and Helping Artists, One NFT at a Time
description: Lika Spivakovska, the owner of two art galleries in Kyiv, Ukraine, has partnered with an NFT gallery in Puerto Rico to auction off pictures of art damaged and created during the war. The money will go to Ukrainian artists and other humanitarian aid.
content: Lika Spivakovska closed her two art galleries in Kyiv, Ukraine, hours after Russia invaded her country and felt helpless as she traveled across Europe, seeking refuge with her two children. Artists stuck in Ukraine had been messaging her all week, saying that their home workshops and studios had been destroyed by attackers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Golden-Con Threw a Party, Invited Every ‘Golden Girls’ Fan It Knew
description: Thousands gathered in Chicago to celebrate the beloved sitcom, whose fan base has only expanded since its original run and made the Girls into L.G.B.T.Q. icons.
content: CHICAGO — Bird Milliken designs “Golden Girls”-themed greeting cards under the label Lipstick on a Turd. Her advice? Find yourself a man who’s into watching “The Golden Girls.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Free Childhood Memories Trapped in Ancient Film
description: If you have decades of family history stored on old slides and negatives, you can easily convert those pictures to digital photos.
content: Photography began to go digital about 30 years ago, so if you’re older than that your relatives probably documented a portion of your childhood on film-based formats, like slides or prints made from negatives. Or maybe you have stacks of your old slides and negatives from long-lost pictures boxed up in the attic or garage. While not quite as simple as scanning old photo prints, digitizing that film rescues family history from outdated media and makes it easy to share the restored memories. Here are a few ways to get the job done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Do Americans Support Abortion Rights? Depends on the State.
description: Polling suggests an overturning of Roe v. Wade might not carry political consequences in states that would be likeliest to put in restrictions.
content: A majority of Americans believe that abortion should be legal in all or most cases. But the story is more complicated in the states where the future of abortion policy is likely to be decided if — as is now expected — the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Vance Wins Republican Senate Primary in Ohio After Nod From Trump
description: J.D. Vance, the author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” won a G.O.P. race that saw nearly $80 million in television advertising.
content: CINCINNATI — J.D. Vance, the best-selling author whose “Hillbilly Elegy” about life in Appalachia illuminated a slice of the country that felt left behind, decisively won the Ohio Senate primary on Tuesday after a late endorsement by Donald J. Trump helped him surge past his rivals in a crowded field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: For Second Straight Year, California Sees a Population Decline
description: Blame the pandemic, falling birthrates, immigration restrictions and an exodus of residents looking for cheaper places to live.
content: LOS ANGELES — Deaths from Covid. Aging baby boomers. Fewer children. Restrictions on immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Ukraine’s Battlefield Is Haunted by Putin’s Chemical Weapons Legacy
description: While the risk remains ambiguous, the Russian leader’s long infatuation with the toxic arms fuels worries that the deadly poisons could be deployed in Ukraine.
content: In September 2017, as President Vladimir V. Putin presided over the televised destruction of what he called the last of Russia’s chemical arms, he hailed their elimination as “a huge step towards making the modern world more balanced and safe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Vanishing Variants: Lessons from Gamma, Iota and Mu
description: Studying the coronavirus variants that have faded away could help us prepare for what comes next, scientists say.
content: In early 2021, scientists in Colombia discovered a worrisome new coronavirus variant. This variant, eventually known as Mu, had several troubling mutations that experts believed could help it evade the immune system’s defenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Secretary Blinken tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: A State Department spokesman said Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken had not seen President Biden in several days.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken has tested positive for the coronavirus, the State Department announced on Wednesday, nearly a week before he was scheduled to travel to diplomatic meetings in Europe and Morocco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German exports to Russia fall 62% as sanctions take a toll.
description: But despite the sanctions, German companies still sold 1 billion euros in goods to Russia in March.
content: German exports to Russia plunged 62.3 percent in March from the previous month, government statistics showed Wednesday, as sanctions aimed at starving the Russian economy as punishment for President Vladimir V. Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine took hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Elif Ince
title: Turkey’s Plan to Draw Refugees Back to Syria: Homes for 1 Million
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Turkey will build homes, schools, hospitals and more in northern Syria, but experts question whether refugees will return willingly.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey this week announced a dramatic expansion of his country’s plan to entice refugees from Syria’s civil war to return to their home country by building homes for them in Syria near the Turkish border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Myth of the Genius Tech Inventor
description: We idolize founders with brilliant ideas, but triumph often results from business savvy combined with imagination.
content: It’s practically an insult in Silicon Valley to say that an executive is extremely capable at running a company. Inventors, not great managers, are often the ones celebrated in technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Penguins Edge Rangers in Triple Overtime to Take Game 1
description: The first N.H.L. playoff game at Madison Square Garden in five years featured just about everything a hockey game could, except for a win by the home team.
content: Welcome back to the postseason, New York Rangers. The intensity, the pace, referees letting both teams play on. And on and on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Shockwaves from a Supreme Court leak.
content: The Supreme Court confirmed that a leaked draft ruling to overturn the landmark Roe v. Wade decision on abortion rights was authentic, but said it was not final. The disclosure triggered protests outside the court, as well as political upheaval with potentially broad electoral and legal consequences. Here’s a guide to the Mississippi law at the center of the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Once Close Allies, Roberts and Alito Have Taken Divergent Paths
description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. have become emblems of a stark divide at the Supreme Court as it confronts whether to overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: WASHINGTON — There was a time when Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., the author of the leaked draft opinion on abortion that rocked the nation on Monday night, was Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s closest ally on the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $475,000 Homes in Massachusetts, Oklahoma and Virginia
description: A Cape Cod-style cottage in Amherst, a Prairie-style house in Oklahoma City and a 1913 home in Norfolk.
content: Amherst is a charming college town in the Pioneer Valley region of western Massachusetts, with a highly ranked liberal arts school and a flagship state university. This house is a few blocks from the University of Massachusetts Amherst and half a block from a bus stop; the bus ride to Main Street, lined with restaurants and country inns, takes about 10 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Space Cats to the Mexican Revolution
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: NOUR’S SECRET LIBRARY, by Wafa Tarnowska. Illustrated by Vali Mintzi. (Barefoot Books, cloth, $17.99; paper, $9.99, ages 6 to 10.) Mintzi, who grew up in Romania and lives in the Middle East, uses charcoal for war-torn Damascus and earth-toned gouache for the dreams of a girl named Nour (“light” in Arabic) in the Lebanese-born Tarnowska’s hopeful picture book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Oklahoma bans abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy.
description: Gov. Kevin Stitt signed the Oklahoma Heartbeat Act, modeled on the law restricting abortions that came into effect in Texas last year.
content: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma on Tuesday signed a bill prohibiting abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, the latest attempt by Republican lawmakers in the state to find legal avenues to ban abortions that will withstand judicial challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Ban on Russian Oil?
description: The E.U. proposed a total embargo.
content: With no end to the Ukraine conflict in sight, the European Union took a major step on Wednesday toward weakening Moscow’s ability to finance the war, proposing a total embargo on Russian oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Lessons from a Lesser Variant
description: Variants that have faded are giving scientists insight into what comes next.
content: Do you remember Mu?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Pigeons, Community Diversity, Film Club
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about city pigeons, think about diversity in their community, watch a film about noticing the world around you, make observations about a photograph and imagine your own Little Free Library.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Janzen
title: ‘How Do You Do?’ On Being a Gentleman in 21st-Century Ballet
description: A City Ballet dancer considers the politics of two bodies dancing together as he seeks to make sense of his art form and partnering in a changing world.
content: In one of my first performances of George Balanchine’s “Agon,” I stood onstage, uncomfortable, while my partner, Teresa Reichlen, danced her short solo. I’d just cranked her foot to her head a few times and we were about to reunite for a kind of rubber-banding push-and-pull section. I thought: “I shouldn’t be out here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Few Transgender Children Change Their Minds After 5 Years, Study Finds
description: But the study, which began in 2013, may not fully reflect what’s happening today, when many more children are identifying as trans.
content: Young children who transition to a new gender with social changes — taking on new names, pronouns, haircuts and clothing — are likely to continue identifying as that gender five years later, according to a report published on Wednesday, the first study of its kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wyna Liu
title: The Folded Puzzle
description: Wyna Liu, a New York Times Crossword editor, examines a nontraditional crossword puzzle.
content: Welcome to The Lab, a new series that examines a nontraditional puzzle that pushes boundaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Amber Heard Testifies About a ‘Pattern’ of Violence by Johnny Depp
description: Ms. Heard took the stand for the first time in the defamation case filed against her by the actor, her ex-husband, who says he was damaged by an op-ed she wrote.
content: Amber Heard, an actress defending herself against a defamation lawsuit filed by her ex-husband, Johnny Depp, took the stand on Wednesday, recalling how a whirlwind romance that started on a movie set descended into a “pattern” of violence perpetrated against her by the actor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: J.D. Vance’s Rise From ‘Hillbilly Elegy’ Author to Senate Nominee
description: Now the Republican nominee for Senate in Ohio, Mr. Vance owes his ascendant political career in large part to Donald Trump, whose style he has tried to emulate.
content: Before the 2016 election, J.D. Vance called Donald J. Trump “cultural heroin” and a demagogue who was “leading the white working class to a very dark place.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Steinberger
title: No American Has Ever Been No. 1 in Squash. Amanda Sobhy Can Change That.
description: The first American-born player to crack the world’s Top 10 is taking on Egypt’s dominance of the game.
content: Amanda Sobhy took the court for her first match at the Windy City Open on a snowy Thursday evening in late February. The $500,000 tournament, one of the richest events in pro squash, was being held at the University Club of Chicago, around the corner from Grant Park; a portable glass-walled court had been set up on the ninth floor, in a room known as Cathedral Hall, a space that called to mind a medieval church. Despite the weather, 100 or so spectators had come out to watch. A few days later, the tennis legend Billie Jean King would attend the semifinals and finals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Launches Ballistic Missile Ahead of Yoon’s Inauguration
description: Kim Jong-un has sought to improve the North’s nuclear capabilities and gain diplomatic leverage with Washington and the incoming administration of Yoon Suk-yeol.
content: SEOUL — North Korea launched a ballistic missile off its east coast on Wednesday, just days before a new South Korean president was scheduled to take office, South Korean officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: This Year’s Tony Awards Will Be Hosted by Ariana DeBose
description: The nominees are to be announced on Monday, and the awards ceremony is to take place on June 12.
content: Ariana DeBose will host this year’s Tony Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: What to Know Before Seeing ‘Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness’
description: Why do Wanda Maximoff and our title hero seem to be zombies, and what is the Darkhold? Here’s a rundown and a viewing guide to help.
content: It was already challenging enough to keep up with the 27 films and half-dozen Disney+ TV shows in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. But now, in “Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness,” out Friday, you also have to keep track of multiple versions of Dr. Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch) and Wanda Maximoff (Elizabeth Olsen), also known as the Scarlet Witch. And who knows who else — it is the multiverse, after all, so there are multiple versions of, well, everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Trump Win in Ohio
description: We look at last night’s election results.
content: Most one-term presidents recede from the political scene, with their party’s voters happy to see them go. But Donald Trump continues to dominate the Republican Party a year and a half after he lost re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Reviving the Renaissance Temples of Venice’s Jewish Ghetto
description: An $11 million project is underway to restore three decaying synagogues and preserve the city’s history of harboring European Jews.
content: VENICE — Walking into the Jewish Ghetto here, in the Cannaregio section of this watery city, you would not know that there are five ornate synagogues nestled behind the walls of the nondescript tenements that date back to the 16th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Michael Wines
title: Leak Heightens the Perception of a Politicized Supreme Court
description: Even some harsh critics of Roe v. Wade see a court that reflects and amplifies the nation’s political divides.
content: The revelation of a Supreme Court draft opinion that would overrule Roe v. Wade has caused many Americans to express doubts about whether the justices are guided by the law rather than by their political beliefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Sean Piccoli
title: ‘Anarchy Row’ Becomes Ground Zero in Fight Against Homeless Sweeps
description: Eight protesters were arrested as police and sanitation workers cleared an encampment near Tompkins Square Park.
content: On Wednesday morning at the miniature tent city across the street from Tompkins Square Park, the protesters were ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Cate Blanchett and Cindy Sherman: Secrets of the Camera Chameleons
description: On the 45th anniversary of Sherman’s acclaimed series “Untitled Film Stills,” they toured her show, discussing what an image, or a smile, may reveal.
content: Cindy Sherman and Cate Blanchett had only met in passing, a few times. And yet there is an identifiable thread connecting the work of Sherman, the artist who (dis)appears, disguised in character, in her own photographs, and Blanchett, the protean and Oscar-winning Australian actress. On a gray morning in late April, the women, mutual admirers, convened at Hauser & Wirth gallery on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where a collection of Sherman’s critically acclaimed early work opened May 4, and where they quickly forged a connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: What is a trigger law? And which states have them?
description: More than a dozen states have implemented legislation that would outlaw or severely restrict abortions, on the assumption that the Supreme Court will overturn Roe v. Wade this summer.
content: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, it would not outlaw abortion. Instead, states would be able to individually determine the procedure’s legality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Wish You Were Here’ Review: The Saga of Female Friendship
description: Sanaz Toossi’s new play follows a group of five women in Iran as they and their friendships change against the backdrop of marriages and revolution.
content: The five Iranian women of “Wish You Were Here,” which opened on Tuesday night at Playwrights Horizons, joke about sex and their bodies. They file one another’s toenails and lick their cheeks with a disarming degree of comfort. And they show off their psychic connections by playing rounds of “What am I thinking?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fahima Haque
title: Which states are reinforcing abortion rights?
description: Several states have already taken steps to protect abortion rights, and many are taking additional measures in anticipation of the Supreme Court ruling.
content: Out of 50 states, there are 13 that have passed so-called trigger laws that would outlaw abortion if the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade. But what’s happening in states that do not have a trigger law?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Diego Maradona’s ‘Hand of God’ Jersey Sells for $9.3 Million
description: The shirt worn by the Argentine soccer star when he scored two fabled goals, one of which he attributed to divine aid, fetched what is believed to be the highest price ever paid for a sports item.
content: During the quarterfinals of the 1986 World Cup, the English soccer player Steve Hodge looped a ball to his goalie that was intercepted by the Argentine soccer legend Diego Maradona, enabling Maradona to score one of the most notorious goals against Hodge’s team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: ‘A Monster in Our Midst’: How a Tattoo Industry #MeToo Case Collapsed
description: Isaiah “Toothtaker” Camacho was a star in the underground tattoo industry, even as sexual assault accusations against him piled up.
content: It was past midnight in a dark bar in Bushwick last summer, and the man at the counter was furious. Short and covered in ominous tattoos — including one across his forehead that read “I WANT TO KILL YOU” — the man accused the bartender of using the wrong liquor in his drink. Incensed, he slammed his glass down, grinding the bar to a halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: LinkedIn Agrees to Pay $1.8 Million to Women Over Discrimination Claims
description: The professional networking platform reached a settlement with the U.S. Labor Department over allegations that it underpaid 686 female employees in California from 2015 to 2017, officials said.
content: LinkedIn, the professional networking platform, has reached an agreement with the U.S. Department of Labor to pay $1.8 million to female employees who the agency said received far less compensation than their male colleagues from 2015 to 2017, the department said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike, Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
title: Leaked Threat to Roe v. Wade Stuns, Then Energizes Americans
description: Supporters and opponents of abortion rights were anticipating a Supreme Court decision this summer, but the sudden release of a draft opinion set off a wave of impromptu protests.
content: Opponents and supporters of abortion rights had expected for months that the Supreme Court would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade, but the leaked draft opinion late Monday came as if out of the blue, setting off shock, outrage and jubilation on both sides of the nation’s deeply polarized abortion debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: What to Know About the Triple Crown
description: Horse racing’s rarest and grandest prize begins Saturday with the Kentucky Derby.
content: In 1919, Sir Barton became the first of 13 horses to win the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes, capturing what would become known as the Triple Crown, horse racing’s most cherished and yet elusive prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Reacts to the Supreme Court Leak
description: “Congratulations, ladies, your decisions are being made by four dudes and a woman who thinks ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’ is a rom-com,” Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: Abortion Is a Business Issue
description: Women make up half of the work force, but the issue’s divisiveness has led many companies to keep quiet on the issue for now.
content: After a Supreme Court draft ruling showed that Roe v. Wade may be overturned, many of America’s corporate leaders reacted with silence. Abortion is a business issue: Women make up more than half of the work force, and those who were unable to get abortions were less likely to be employed full time six months after denial of care, according to a 2018 paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Looming Rent Increase of Up to 9 Percent Tests Adams’s Housing Priorities
description: Some Democrats are calling proposed increases for New York City’s roughly one million rent-stabilized apartments “unconscionable.” Mayor Eric Adams says he wants to support small landlords.
content: When he ran for mayor, Eric Adams positioned himself as a champion for the working class — a lifelong New Yorker who had grown up in poverty and won support from voters in the boroughs outside Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Sophie Kasakove and J. David Goodman
title: Rising Anxiety and Increased Demand at America’s Imperiled Abortion Clinics
description: On Tuesday, it was business as usual. But abortion providers, many of whom anticipated being shut down, worried about the future health and safety of their patients.
content: On the calendar at Jackson Women’s Health Organization on Tuesday, every appointment slot was filled. Patients drove in from across Mississippi, as well as from Louisiana, Tennessee and as far away as Texas, taking the long trip to obtain an abortion from a clinic that now seemed doomed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Smoke and Sandstorm, Seen From Space
description: A time-lapse image of smoke from wildfires in New Mexico and dust from a storm in Colorado illustrates the scope of Western catastrophe.
content: The video is mesmerizing: As three whitish-gray geysers gush eastward from the mountains of New Mexico, a sheet of brown spills down from the north like swash on a beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Bank of America will pay $10 million for improperly garnishing customer accounts.
description: The bank let creditors take funds from customers’ accounts even when state laws should have barred them from doing so. And it charged those customers fees for the operation.
content: Bank of America is paying $10 million to settle a regulator’s claim that it illegally helped some creditors strip funds out of its customers’ accounts, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: A handful of coronavirus cases emerge after the White House Correspondents’ Dinner.
description: Cases are not uncommon in Washington these days, and there is no certainty that those who tested positive were infected at the dinner.
content: A handful of coronavirus cases have emerged among people who attended the White House Correspondents’ Dinner over the weekend, the president of the correspondents’ association said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Larry Hogan Takes the Fight to Trump From Within the G.O.P.
description: The Maryland governor, a rare Republican who speaks out publicly against Donald Trump, is trying to defend G.O.P. lawmakers targeted by the former president.
content: Greetings from your co-hosts Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam. We have an item tonight from our colleague Luke Broadwater, who reports on an effort by Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland to push back against Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilaria Parogni
title: The History of Cinco de Mayo and How It’s Celebrated
description: There is more to this celebration of Mexican heritage than beer, mariachi bands and wild parties.
content: More than being an excuse to treat oneself to nachos, tacos, mezcal and margaritas, Cinco de Mayo has a history that runs deep and continues to serve as a vehicle conveying Mexican culture, pride and values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Heartbroken
description: Have you ever experienced heartbreak? How did you cope?
content: A recent Times article examined heartbreak, the trauma surrounding it and potential ways of dealing with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Times Reaches 9.1 Million Subscribers
description: The purchase of The Athletic helped the company get closer to its new subscriber goal, but the sports site lost $6.8 million over two months, eating into overall profits.
content: Aided by the recent addition of the sports website The Athletic, The New York Times Company said on Wednesday that it had added 387,000 net digital subscribers in the first quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Anton Troianovski
title: What is Russia’s May 9 Victory Day and why is it so significant this year?
description: In the two decades that Vladimir V. Putin has led Russia, the country’s Victory Day marches, honoring Soviet sacrifices of World War II, have transformed into huge military spectacles and nostalgic celebrations.
content: Marked by grandiose speeches, a colossal parade and a show of military might on Red Square, Russia’s Victory Day on May 9, a holiday celebrating the Soviet Union’s vanquishing of Nazi Germany, has taken on particular resonance this year with Russia mired in a war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams and Tania Ganguli
title: Why Brittney Griner Could Be the Last American Basketball Star in Russia
description: The atrocities of the war in Ukraine and Griner’s detention in Russia on drug charges could cut off a lucrative pipeline for women’s basketball players.
content: Mike Cound had decided on a figure — a reasonable salary request, he said — for a client who wanted to play for UMMC Yekaterinburg, a professional women’s basketball team in Russia. As an experienced sports agent, that was what he was supposed to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: The Fight Over Abortion History
description: The leaked draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade also takes aim at its version of history, challenging decades of scholarship that argues abortion was not always a crime.
content: History, and arguments about history, have long been central to abortion jurisprudence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arya Sundaram
title: New Jersey Man Is Sentenced to 14 Years in Online Dating Scheme
description: Rubbin Sarpong and his co-conspirators posed as U.S. service members on dating websites, stealing $1.75 million from more than 40 victims, prosecutors said.
content: A New Jersey man has been sentenced to 14 years in prison for his role in an online dating scheme in which he and others, posing as U.S. military personnel serving overseas, stole $1.75 million from more than 40 victims over four years, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: With Late Rally, Real Madrid Overcomes City and Outdoes Itself
description: All but beaten in its Champions League semifinal, Madrid scored once, then twice, then a third time to snatch a victory and add to its legend.
content: MADRID — There was nothing. There was no noise. The Santiago Bernabéu stood silent, subdued, waiting for the bell to toll. There was no spark. Real Madrid had long since run out of ideas, and they were running low on hope, too. Most pressingly, there was no time. There were 30 seconds left, plus maybe a little extra purgatory, and then it would be over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Should You Subscribe to Your Next Vacation?
description: You can subscribe to music and movies. Why not travel? New services target frequent travelers, luxury lovers, bargain shoppers and even Tesla fans.
content: Music, movies, meals and even shaving supplies have all successfully been sold by subscription. But should you subscribe to your next vacation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Dolly Parton Voted Into Rock Hall Alongside Eminem and Lionel Richie
description: The country singer had objected to being included, but will join a class that includes Carly Simon, Duran Duran and others from across genres.
content: Despite a last-minute plea to “respectfully bow out” of consideration for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, the country singer Dolly Parton made it in anyway, joining a musically diverse array of inductees for 2022 that also includes Eminem, Lionel Richie, Carly Simon, Eurythmics, Duran Duran and Pat Benatar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Moderna reaps $5.9 billion from its Covid-19 vaccine sales.
description: Stéphane Bancel, the company’s chief executive officer, said Moderna has $21 billion worth of advance purchase agreements for the vaccine.
content: Moderna reported on Wednesday that sales for its Covid-19 vaccine more than tripled in the first three months of 2022 compared to the same period a year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: The E.U. moves to shut off Russian oil
description: The proposed ban would halt imports of crude oil in the next six months.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Maria Cramer and Mike Ives
title: Dave Chappelle Attacked While Performing at the Hollywood Bowl
description: A man armed with a fake gun was arrested after tackling the comedian as he performed in Los Angeles, the police said.
content: Dave Chappelle was finishing his standup act at the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles late Tuesday night when a man armed with a fake gun hurled himself at the comedian, knocking him to the floor and shocking the crowd, according to the police and witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Crumbling Russian ‘Spyville’ Returns to Polish Hands
description: A Warsaw housing complex built in the 1970s and rented by Russia was reputed to be a nest of spies. The city’s government has seized the site and pledged to hand it over to the Ukrainian community.
content: WARSAW — Soviet diplomats moved out of the hulking Warsaw housing compound more than 30 years ago. But some Russians stayed behind, sheltering until the early 2000s behind a fence topped with barbed wire from a city that, with the collapse of their empire, had suddenly become hostile territory — and an important intelligence target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: L.A. Dance Project Celebrates Female Choreographers
description: The best part? It’s not cosmetic. New York premieres by Madeline Hollander and Janie Taylor pair perfectly with a Bella Lewitzky revival.
content: When Benjamin Millepied created L.A. Dance Project 10 years ago, the company ran hot and cold. The new works, mainly by Millepied, were neither lasting nor particularly vivid, but his eye for older dances, by choreographers like Merce Cunningham and William Forsythe, showed impeccable taste. He was delivering on part of his mission: to bring quality dance to Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Joel Embiid Is Carving a Path Into the Heart of Philadelphia
description: Embiid came into his own this season, positioning the Sixers for a run at a championship. Yet another injury may derail that goal, but he has earned respect.
content: There was a time when it wasn’t certain that the Philadelphia 76ers should be placed on the broad shoulders of Joel Embiid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: At the Original Speed
description: Eric Bornstein’s puzzle joins the foreign service.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Please welcome back the constructor Eric Bornstein, who is making his 10th appearance in the New York Times Crossword. Mr. Bornstein’s new puzzle features a clever wordplay theme with a tidy revealer — more on that below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Rob Szypko, Chelsea Daniel, Anita Badejo, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Is This How Roe Ends?
description: A leaked draft opinion from the Supreme Court suggested that it was preparing to overturn the constitutional right to abortion.
content: The revelation that the Supreme Court could end the constitutional right to abortion in the United States has set off a political firestorm and deepened divisions about one of the most contentious issues in American society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: Japan Says It Needs Nuclear Power. Can Host Towns Ever Trust It Again?
description: The Ukraine war has shown the fragility of Japan’s energy supplies. But the decision to restart plants after the Fukushima disaster is fraught with emotions and political calculation.
content: KASHIWAZAKI, Japan — Growing up, Mika Kasahara saw the nuclear power plant that hugs the coast of her hometown simply as the place where her father worked, a familiar fortress of cooling tanks and steel lightning towers overlooking the Sea of Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Erich Barnes, Star Defensive Back for the 1960s Giants, Dies at 86
description: A speedy cornerback who also played for the Chicago Bears and the Cleveland Browns, he was often matched against the league’s best wide receivers.
content: Erich Barnes, the hard-hitting, speedy cornerback who helped propel the Giants to three consecutive N.F.L. championship games in the early 1960s, died on Friday in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Oath Keepers Leader Sought to Ask Trump to Unleash His Militia
description: A dramatic account of how the militia leader, Stewart Rhodes, tried to reach Donald J. Trump on Jan. 6 with a message that the group could help keep him in power was revealed in federal court.
content: Even as the beleaguered police were still trying to disperse a violent mob at the Capitol last January, Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the far-right Oath Keepers militia, undertook a desperate, last-ditch effort to keep President Donald J. Trump in the White House, according to court papers released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Jane Coaston, Michelle Cottle and Ross Douthat
title: Is This Trump’s World Now? Four Opinion Writers on the Roe Leak and Vance’s Big Win
description: And what does it mean for Democrats if it is?
content: During a seismic week in American politics, one clear winner has emerged: former President Donald Trump. The three Supreme Court justices he nominated appear poised to deliver a long-sought victory to the right by overturning Roe v. Wade, after a draft of the anticipated Dobbs decision was leaked Monday evening. The next day, the “Hillbilly Elegy” author J.D. Vance won his race in the Republican Senate primary in Ohio after Mr. Trump’s endorsement resuscitated his sluggish campaign. What do the events of this week mean for both parties as they look ahead to the midterm elections? The Times Opinion writers Jane Coaston, Michelle Cottle and Ross Douthat discuss what this moment means for the U.S. political landscape with the Times Opinion podcast host Lulu Garcia-Navarro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Arnstein
title: #VanLife, From the Passenger Seat
description: When Caity Weaver wanted to try living out of a van as research for an article, she recruited her friend Michael Arnstein to come along for the ride. He shares what it was like to ride shotgun for a week.
content: When my friend Caity Weaver called me out of the blue to propose joining her for a weeklong excursion in a camper van, I thought, this could be amazing, followed immediately by, could this be a huge mistake?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: European Union Takes a Leap With a Russian Oil Embargo
description: The ban, once seen as unlikely, is a significant tightening of the squeeze on Russia’s economy, and a financial blow to Europe, too.
content: More than two months into Russia’s brutal war on Ukraine, the European Union on Wednesday announced plans to embargo Russian oil, its biggest economic sacrifice yet to inflict pain on the Russian economy and President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Montgomery, N.J.: An Under-the-Radar Suburb Near Princeton
description: This Somerset County township may not be as well known as its famous neighbor, but residents take pride in their ‘wonderful community’ and its growing diversity.
content: Montgomery, at the southern border of Somerset County in New Jersey, has a bit of an identity problem: The 32-square-mile township is difficult to find on many maps because its name is often omitted, while the names of its northern and southern neighborhoods appear instead. To make things even more confusing, a number of Montgomery’s homes have ZIP codes that correspond to better-known communities like Hillsborough and Princeton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mireille Silcoff
title: It’s Been an Interesting Few Years in Cough-Drop Advertising
description: Is there a harder sell than products designed to suppress, and thus hide, respiratory illness during a pandemic?
content: A little more than two years ago, when having a cough or a runny nose did not yet mean becoming a controversial person, advertising for over-the-counter cold-relief medications reached its most bullying era. Vicks ran miserable ads with lines like “moms don’t take sick days” and variations saying the same of dads, bridesmaids and winter Olympians. The manufacturer of Halls, one of America’s best-selling cough-drop brands, went even more hardcore, creating commercials in which clearly sick workers — a coughing, saggy-eyed security guard; a white-lipped supermarket stocker with a sleeve full of tissues — were dressed down by a drill-sergeant type: “You don’t cough! You don’t show defeat! You don’t clear that throat! Do you hear me?” This was tough messaging, designed for a hustle-culture, gig-economy, no-security world: No matter how sick you are, days off are for losers. Take the medicine and get ’er done.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love the Horn
description: Listen to music that shows off the golden, mellow sunshine of “the cello of the brass section.”
content: In the past we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, piano, opera, cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, flute, string quartets, tenors, Brahms, choral music, percussion, symphonies, Stravinsky, trumpet, Maria Callas, Bach, the organ, mezzo-sopranos, music for dance, Wagner and Renaissance music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg, Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Lauren Hirsch
title: Corporate America Doesn’t Want to Talk Abortion, but It May Have To
description: In a deeply divided nation, public statements on Roe v. Wade can affect everything from recruiting to a company’s bottom line. So far, that has kept almost everyone quiet.
content: Some political and cultural events set off a cascade of emails from brands — sneaker, makeup and food companies telling their customers that they stand with them in a stressful time, or reminding them to vote. But after a draft opinion obtained by Politico revealed the Supreme Court’s intention to overturn Roe v. Wade, the overwhelming reaction from corporate leaders was silence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: The Dish Our Customers Will Never Let Us Take Off the Menu
description: Chargrilled broccoli with slivers of fried garlic and red chile is a fixture at Yotam Ottolenghi’s delis. There’s a good reason.
content: In my restaurants and delis — as with all restaurants and delis — there’s a lot of movement: movement, turnover and energy. Customers and dishes come and go, seasons and menus change, one service gives way to the next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Yankees Run Win Streak to 11 With Pummeling of Blue Jays
description: Jameson Taillon got more than enough backing in an easy win. The Mets, meanwhile, took both games in a doubleheader against Atlanta.
content: TORONTO — A big blast from Aaron Judge put the surging Yankees on the path to yet another win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Hochul Chooses a Congressman Who Has Won in a Swing District
description: Antonio Delgado will replace Brian Benjamin as the governor’s running mate in the upcoming Democratic primary.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll meet the man Gov. Kathy Hochul has chosen to be the new lieutenant governor. We’ll also check on how a federal rule about light bulbs will make New York look a little different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: Rising Violence by Separatists Adds to Pakistan’s Lethal Instability
description: A government plagued by volatility is trying to quell a separatist movement in Baluchistan while also fighting other insurgencies and striving for economic development.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Shari Baluch was a 30-year-old mother of two children and a schoolteacher. Late last month, on a university campus in Karachi, Pakistan’s biggest city, she detonated a suicide bomb, killing herself and four others, including three Chinese teachers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Intuit Will Refund $141 Million to Low-Income TurboTax Users
description: In a settlement, the software company admitted no wrongdoing but agreed to repay fees it had charged millions of Americans for returns that the authorities said were falsely advertised as free.
content: For years, the maker of the TurboTax software claimed that people could file their tax returns online for free. Millions of customers signed up, only to pay hidden fees later in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: George D. Gould, a Pillar in N.Y.’s Fiscal Rescue, Dies at 94
description: As a Republican Wall Street financier recruited by Mayor Beame, he helped make the city’s effort to restore stability more credible.
content: George D. Gould, a Wall Street financier who was a figure of calm in New York’s convulsive mid-1970s fiscal crisis and an original member of the state agency created to borrow on behalf of a nearly-bankrupt New York City, died on April 26 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Daniel Berehulak
title: In Mexico, One Cartel Is Cleared, but Others Storm In
description: In the state of Michoacán, small drug cartels compete with larger ones for territory, leaving the residents caught in the middle of a brutal turf war.
content: EL AGUAJE, Mexico — Antonio had grown limes and raised cattle on his farm in western Mexico for years, managing to eke out a living by following a rule he and many others in Michoacán, one of Mexico’s most violent states, had always known: Leave the narco-trafficking routes alone and no harm would come their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: American Importers Accuse Shipping Giants of Profiteering
description: Carriers are exploiting the supply chain chaos to breach contracts and jack up rates, importers say in asking for federal intervention.
content: David Reich assumed that a contract was a contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Maggie Haberman
title: 5 Takeaways From Ohio’s Primary Elections
description: Donald Trump showed his enduring grip over Republican primaries for Senate, and establishment Democrats won a House rematch against a progressive challenger.
content: It was an early night in Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Louvre Bids to Keep a Chardin Bought by U.S. Museum in France
description: The Kimbell Art Museum in Texas is revealed to be the buyer of “Basket of Wild Strawberries,” at auction. The Louvre has been working to name it a national treasure.
content: On a computer screen, the still life “Basket of Wild Strawberries” by the 18th-century French painter Jean Siméon Chardin is quiet and unassuming.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Crosby, 17 Seasons On, Is Not Going Anywhere
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 4, 2022.
content: “I mean, I’m a lot closer to the end than I am in the middle. I understand that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: How Good Are You at Recycling?
description: Are you savvy when it comes to recycling rules? How much effort do you put into properly disposing of waste?
content: How frequently do you recycle? Are you conscious about what, or how much, you put in the garbage?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bennett Madison
title: A Gay Icon From Reality TV’s Early Years Makes a Hesitant Return
description: Danny Roberts, a star of “The Real World” on MTV, brought a sense of possibility to the pop culture landscape during a fraught time for gay representation.
content: GRAFTON, Vt. — When you cross into Vermont from New York, the road opens up and the Green Mountains emerge. Make it to Grafton (population: 645), and your cell service largely evaporates. This was where, on a recent day, Danny Roberts was standing in the doorway of the tiny cabin in the woods where he lives with his 6-year-old daughter. His eyes are crinkly now; his sandy hair seems uncertain of its next move. He has grown out a beard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness’ Review: Nothing Out of the Ordinary
description: Benedict Cumberbatch returns for some more mystic Marvel mumbo-jumbo, though Sam Raimi manages to inject a sense of horror every now and then.
content: Strange? Madness? Let’s not get carried away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Neal Adams, Who Gave Batman a Darker Look, Dies at 80
description: He brought an earthy realism (and a new adversary or two) to the superhero characters he drew. He also championed the rights of comic book creators.
content: Neal Adams, a leading comic book artist who brought a visceral realism to his depictions of superheroes, notably helping to revitalize Batman by giving him a darker image and new adversaries, while also championing the rights of comic book creators, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: The Stories Behind Some of the Weird Stuff on ‘Severance’
description: Catherine Miller, the show’s prop master, talks about how her team sourced and made the eerie objects that define Lumon.
content: It’s hard not to notice the stuff on the Apple+ series “Severance”: the bulky old computers; the Chinese finger traps that mock modern office incentives; the phones that are, for once, not iPhones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Brara
title: Paris, Europe’s Former Art Capital, Is Back on Top
description: Largely thanks to a wave of new galleries with internationally minded programs, the city has recaptured some of the energy and excitement of a bygone era.
content: IT’S HARD TO pinpoint exactly why so much influential creative work came out of Paris in the 1920s, but what is certain is that its originators — or at least the white and usually male ones among them — felt free. For a while, it seemed enough, as Ernest Hemingway writes in “A Moveable Feast” (1964), “just to be back in our part of Paris and away from the track and to bet on our own life and work, and on the painters that you knew.” That he mentions his painter friends reflects the artistic era’s ample cross-pollination among disciplines and alludes to its frenetic socializing — at those famous libation-fueled Saturday salons of Gertrude Stein’s, for one, where Pablo Picasso and Henri Matisse would mingle with F. Scott Fitzgerald, Ezra Pound and Edith Sitwell. When the sun came up the next day, some would seek solitude, but others would head to a favorite cafe to discuss their lives and their work and what one had or didn’t have to do with the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: New York City pension funds sue Activision over financial records.
description: The funds claim Activision failed to turn over records as they investigate whether Activision secured a fair price in its planned sale to Microsoft.
content: Five New York City employee pension groups that own stock in Activision Blizzard, the embattled video game maker, are suing Activision, saying that the company failed to turn over financial records as the groups try to investigate whether Activision secured a fair price in its planned sale to Microsoft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Is More War the Only Path to Peace in Ukraine?
description: Western countries are flooding Ukraine with weapons. Can they help end the assault, or will they just make it bloodier?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Was the Strategy Behind the Supreme Court Leak?
description: Was it meant to galvanize the left or right? It is something of a mystery.
content: The leak of a draft Supreme Court decision that would overturn Roe v. Wade is not a surprise, but it is something of a mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Kidd Creole, a Hip-Hop Pioneer, Sentenced to 16 Years in Killing
description: Nathaniel Glover, who had been a member of Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five, stabbed a homeless man on the way to his copy-shop job.
content: Nathaniel Glover, a member of the pioneering hip-hop group Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five, was sentenced Wednesday to 16 years in prison for killing a homeless man in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: The E.U. unveils a plan to ban Russian oil imports.
description: The  proposal will be presented in detail to E.U. ambassadors Wednesday and is expected to be adopted by the end of the week.
content: European Union countries should ban Russian oil imports in the next six months, and all refined oil products by the end of the year, the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, told the European Parliament on Wednesday morning as she unveiled the bloc’s new package of measures against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Man Who Assaulted Flight Attendants Gets 60 Days in Jail
description: After wandering the aisles and assaulting three crew members, Maxwell Berry, a passenger who was flying to Miami, was strapped to his seat with tape.
content: A 23-year-old Ohio man who the authorities say groped two flight attendants and punched a third before being duct-taped to his seat amid jeers from his fellow passengers on a flight last summer was sentenced on Tuesday to 60 days in jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 16 Mother’s Day Dinners So Easy a Kid Could Make Them
description: Put your progeny to work, or make these simply wonderful meals yourself. (Whatever causes you less stress, honestly.)
content: For years, she subsisted on grilled-cheese crusts, congealed oatmeal and browning apple slices the kids left behind, so it’s time to make mom something special. These simple, impressive recipes are great for all ages and skill levels, but, if you have small humans in the house, most 10- or 11-year-olds with some cooking experience can put them together with a little assistance from a grown-up. Even toddlers can help with stirring, pouring, cutting soft vegetables (with a dull-edged dinner knife or plastic knife) or decorating place cards for the table. Once complete, serve it to her, let her eat in peace and please don’t ask her to cut your food.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A 19th-Century French Farmhouse With Period Detail
description: This 19th-century five-bedroom house on the island of Île de Ré, just off France’s mid-Atlantic coast, is on the market for $2.24 million.
content: This 19th-century five-bedroom house on the island of Île de Ré, just off France’s mid-Atlantic coast, is on the market for $2.24 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Montgomery, N.J.
description: This Somerset County township may not be as well known as its neighbors, but residents take pride in their welcoming community and its growing diversity.
content: This Somerset County township may not be as well known as its neighbors, but residents take pride in their welcoming community and its growing diversity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Homes for Sale in New York City
description: This week’s listings are in Midtown, on the Upper East Side and in Flatbush.
content: This week’s listings are in Midtown, on the Upper East Side and in Flatbush.

title: $475,000 Homes in Massachusetts, Oklahoma and Virginia
description: A Cape Cod-style cottage in Amherst, a Prairie-style house in Oklahoma City and a 1913 home in Norfolk.

author: By The New York Times
title: Abortion Rights Demonstrators Rally in U.S. Cities
description: Thousands of protesters took to the streets after a leaked draft decision showed a majority of Supreme Court justices would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: Thousands of protesters took to the streets after a leaked draft decision showed a majority of Supreme Court justices would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade.

author: By Network Pool
title: Schumer Says Senate Will Vote on Federal Abortion Rights Bill
description: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York said that Senate Democrats would bring legislation codifying the right to an abortion to the floor for a vote, though the party lacks the support necessary to pass it.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York said that Senate Democrats would bring legislation codifying the right to an abortion to the floor for a vote, though the party lacks the support necessary to pass it.

title: Corrections: May 4, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 4, 2022.
content: An article on Tuesday about the midterm primaries in Indiana and Ohio misidentified the candidate in an Indiana prosecutor’s race who was endorsed by former Vice President Mike Pence. It was Greg Garrison, not D. Lee Buckingham.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Imagining a Post-Roe America: ‘I Am Scared’
description: A 22-year-old woman fears losing control over her body, and an 80-year-old recalls her illegal abortion. Also: Russian oligarchs’ property; Pelosi in Kyiv.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Hot Dog Party!
description: Pile whatever condiments you have on franks, vegan dogs or brats, and serve with a glass of something cold.
content: Good morning. Some days when dark clouds are scudding in my head and I don’t much feel like cooking — even though cooking’s what I’m here to do — I march myself to the store anyway, and buy a package of hot dogs and another of buns. There’s no finer recourse to feeling low: a hot dog party.
source.name: The New York Times
